title: Favorites/aliases - save commonly used city groups
description:
Save commonly used city groups as named aliases for quick access.

Example:
```
$ t --save team 'sfo jfk lon'
Saved alias 'team'

$ t @team
SFO: ğŸ•“ 15:12:20 (America/Los_Angeles)
JFK: ğŸ•– 18:12:20 (America/New_York)
LON: ğŸ•š 23:12:20 (Europe/London)

$ t --list
team: sfo jfk lon

$ t --delete team
Deleted alias 'team'
```

Store in ~/.config/t/aliases.json or similar. Useful for teams that regularly check the same set of locations.

title: DST change warnings
description:
Warn when Daylight Saving Time changes are imminent (within +/- 5 days).

Example:
```
$ t lon
LON: ğŸ•š 23:30 (+8h) (Europe/London) âš ï¸ DST ends in 3 days (-1h)

$ t sfo
SFO: ğŸ•“ 15:30 (+0h) (America/Los_Angeles) âš ï¸ DST starts in 5 days (+1h)
```

Implementation:
- Check if timezone has DST transition in next/previous 5 days
- Show warning with days until change and direction (+1h or -1h)
- Use Go's time.Location to find transition times
- Could make the window configurable (--dst-warn=7)

This is important for scheduling - offsets change and meetings shift!

title: Calendar integration for holidays
description:
Show if it's a public holiday in the target location.

Example:
```
$ t --cal tyo
TYO: ğŸ•˜ 08:30 Mon Dec 29 ğŸ“… (Bank holiday)

$ t nrt
NRT: ğŸ•˜ 08:30 Mon Jan 1 ğŸŒ New Year's Day (Asia/Tokyo)
```

Options:
- Could use a public holiday API or embed holiday data
- Show holiday name when applicable
- Maybe a --cal flag to explicitly request, or auto-show on holidays
- Consider showing 'weekend' indicator too

Possible data sources:
- https://date.nager.at/Api (free, covers many countries)
- Embedded data for major holidays

Show morning/afternoon/evening/night emoji based on local time.

Example:

title: City name lookup
description:
Allow looking up airport codes and timezones by city name.

Example:
```
$ t --find sao paulo
CGH - Congonhas (SÃ£o Paulo, Brazil) - America/Sao_Paulo
GRU - Guarulhos (SÃ£o Paulo, Brazil) - America/Sao_Paulo

$ t --find tokyo  
NRT - Narita (Tokyo, Japan) - Asia/Tokyo
HND - Haneda (Tokyo, Japan) - Asia/Tokyo

$ t --find new york
JFK - John F Kennedy (New York, USA) - America/New_York
LGA - LaGuardia (New York, USA) - America/New_York
EWR - Newark (New York area, USA) - America/New_York
```

Implementation:
- Add city/country metadata to IATA codes in codes/iata.go
- Fuzzy search on city names
- Show all matching airports with their codes and timezones
- Could also support using city names directly: `t 'sao paulo'` resolves to CGH or GRU

Stretch goal: natural language input that auto-resolves to best match airport

title: Time conversion - show what time it is elsewhere at a specific time
description:
Allow specifying a time at one location and see what time it would be elsewhere.

Example:
```
$ t sfo@9:00 jfk lon
SFO: 09:00  â†’  JFK: 12:00, LON: 17:00
```

Useful for scheduling: 'If I schedule a 9am meeting in SF, what time is that for my colleagues?'

title: Meeting overlap finder - find overlapping work hours across timezones
description:
Find overlapping business hours across multiple timezones.

Example:
```
$ t --overlap sfo lon tyo
Working hours overlap (9am-5pm local):
  17:00-18:00 TYO = 09:00-10:00 LON = 01:00-02:00 SFO
  (1 hour overlap)
```

Could allow customizing work hours (e.g., --hours=8:00-18:00). Helps find meeting times that work for distributed teams.

title: Date display - show date alongside time
description:
Show the date alongside the time, especially useful for seeing when times cross the dateline (e.g., 'tomorrow' in Tokyo when it's evening in SF).

Example:
```
$ t sfo nrt
SFO: ğŸ•“ 15:12:20 Sun Dec 28 (America/Los_Angeles)
NRT: ğŸ•˜ 08:12:20 Mon Dec 29 (Asia/Tokyo)
```

Could be a flag like --date or -d, or always shown when dates differ.

title: Relative offset - show time difference from local timezone
description:
Show the time difference from the user's local timezone next to each result.

Example:
```
$ t lon tyo  # from SF
LON: ğŸ•š 23:12:20 (+8h) (Europe/London)
TYO: ğŸ•˜ 08:12:20 (+17h) (Asia/Tokyo)
```

This helps quickly understand how far ahead/behind a location is.
